chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Javier C Nehmer was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: If a Wisconsin State Prison sentence is imposed, outstanding financial obligations shall be paid from all prison wages at a rate of 25% and the balance due as a condition of extended supervision.  If extended supervision is revoked or will discharge with financial obligations owing, a judgment shall be entered.

miscConds.notes: Bond amount posted shall be applied.  If probation is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.

Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.

Defendant shall not possess or consume any alcohol or controlled substance without a valid prescription and then take medication as prescribed.

Defendant shall have no association with any drug dealers or where drugs are sold.

Defendant shall participate in all counseling and/or treatment programs directed by the probation agent and comply with recommendations.

Defendant shall pay any supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample.

Defendant shall notify the agent of any change in prescription within 48 hours of the change.
